conclusion: Need to use the ideal gas law and properties of the p-V diagram to solve the problem.
State A is at a lower pressure and volume compared to state B; state C is at a higher pressure and volume.
Use the ideal gas law PV = nRT to relate the initial and final states.
Since the temperature T is constant, the ratio of the initial volume to the final volume will be the same.
State A to state B is a decrease in volume, and state B to state C is an increase in volume.
The ratio of the initial volume to the final volume is 1:1.
Use the ideal gas law to find the temperature T at state B; pressure at state B is the same as at state A.
Substitute the known values into the ideal gas law PV = nRT; ratio of the initial pressure to the final pressure is the same as the ratio of the initial volume to the final volume.
Calculate the temperature T at state B using the known temperature at state C and the ratio of the initial volume to the final volume.
Since the temperature is constant, the temperature at state B is the same as at state C.
Verify the calculation by checking the consistency of the derived temperature with the given conditions.
